description:
Arthrobacter pascens is a species of bacteria that belongs to the genus Arthrobacter. It is a Gram-positive, aerobic, and non-spore-forming bacterium. Arthrobacter pascens is typically found in soil environments and is known for its ability to degrade a variety of organic compounds, including aromatic hydrocarbons and pesticides.

The cells of Arthrobacter pascens are coccoid or rod-shaped, and they can undergo a dimorphic life cycle, transitioning between a vegetative state and a resting state. This ability to adapt to different environmental conditions allows Arthrobacter pascens to thrive in diverse soil habitats.

Arthrobacter pascens is considered an important member of the soil microbial community due to its role in the cycling of nutrients and the degradation of various pollutants. It has been the subject of scientific research, particularly in the fields of bioremediation and environmental microbiology, as it may have potential applications in the remediation of contaminated soils and the biodegradation of environmental pollutants.
